question: Which statements correctly describe how the Drain Boundary (DRN) behaves? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! DRN acts as a one-way valve — flow is only allowed from aquifer to drain when $h_{aq} > h_{DRN}$.
error: ❌ Not quite. Remember: DRN is inactive when $h_{aq} ≤ h_{DRN}$ and does not permit inflow into the aquifer.

question: The aquifer head is situated above the drain elevation. What happens when you increase the drain elevation while keeping aquifer head constant? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Well done. A higher drain elevation reduces the head difference and may deactivate the boundary.
error: ❌ Reconsider how head difference and threshold behavior define the flow rate in DRN boundaries.

question: How does the conductance $C_D$ influence the Q–h relationship? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Exactly. Conductance controls flow once active — but the activation threshold is set by $h_{DRN}$ alone.
error: ❌ Not quite. Conductance shapes flow magnitude above threshold but does not influence activation.

question: What are key differences between DRN and RIV boundaries? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. DRN is a one-way outflow mechanism, unlike the bidirectional behavior of RIV.
error: ❌ Review the structural and functional differences between DRN and RIV.

question: Which conditions will lead to zero flow across a DRN boundary? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Yes. Zero flow occurs when head difference is non-positive or when conductance is zero.
error: ❌ Be sure to distinguish between threshold behavior (head) and proportionality (conductance).

question: In a scenario with $h_{aq}$ = 10.5 m, what is the impact of increasing $H_D$ from 9.0 to 10.6 m? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Good analysis. The DRN deactivates once drain elevation exceeds aquifer head.
error: ❌ Review how raising the drain elevation affects the activation threshold and flow.
